title: Alternate names for Light/Roman/Bold
content:
For example, House Industries’ [Chalet](http://web.archive.org/web/20081012141803/http:/www.houseind.com/index.php?page=showfont&id=4&subpage=viewfonts) comes in three different styles (1960, 1970 and 1980) and each has different weights, but instead of light, regular, bold they use Paris, London, New York.

I’m sure there are a bunch of other typefaces that forego the typical weight labels.

Examples would be appreciated!

 [‹ Looking for Norton Utilities 8.0](http://web.archive.org/web/20081012141803/http:/www.typophile.com/node/46127 "Go to previous forum topic") [MicroType Type Ruler cap height percentage Question ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20081012141803/http:/www.typophile.com/node/39910 "Go to next forum topic")
author: armin

comments.content: [PSY/OPS](http://web.archive.org/web/20081012141803/http:/www.typophile.com/wiki/Psy%252BOps) likes to use [A, B, C ... Gauge](http://web.archive.org/web/20081012141803/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/psyops/armchair_modern_set_ot/) for its weight names.

Smeijers uses Blonde, in addition to Normal, Bold, and Black, for Arnhem.

I have a design that I’ve been toying with that I was considering using Soprano, Alto, Tenor, Baritone, and Basso for the weight range. I don’t know if this design will ever see the light of day. (No examples to show, sorry.) Plus, I doubt these designations would pass muster with a typical foundry, not if we wanted wide appeal.

— K.
Museo has 100-900 for the various weights.
Porchez Typofonderie has used Sombre (Ultra Black) and Clair (Light) for Parisine.

[Lexicon](http://web.archive.org/web/20081012141803/http:/www.teff.nl/fonts/lexicon/lexicon.html) goes by a Letter/Number system, ie Roman C No.1

[Ruse](http://web.archive.org/web/20081012141803/http:/www.teff.nl/fonts/ruse/index.html) goes by numbers, from 000 to 100.

And we can’t forget good ol’ Univers with the revolutionary numbering system!

—K
Adobe’s [Multiple Masters](http://web.archive.org/web/20081012141803/http:/kb.adobe.com/selfservice/viewContent.do?externalId=328600) use a combination of numbers and letters.

Fountain’s **Alita** comes in Regular, Bold and [Postmodern](http://web.archive.org/web/20081012141803/http:/www.fountain.nu/catalogue/alita_post.asp). :-)

[EDIT] ...And their [**Super**](http://web.archive.org/web/20081012141803/http:/www.fountain.nu/catalogue/super_normal.asp) is available in Normal, Duper (bold) and Sonic (outline)
Wasn’t their a font that went by cup size?
Maybe I was just remembering [Fast Girls](http://web.archive.org/web/20081012141803/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/pretty/fast-girls/) and the reference to underwire.
